meta.title: Digital Storytelling: A Creator’s Guide to Interactive Entertainment
meta.author: Carolyn Handler Miller

parts.title: Interactive Storytelling: A Journey from Ancient Rituals to Digital Narratives
parts.body: Interactive storytelling is an engaging way of telling stories where the participant becomes a part of the narrative. This form of storytelling has roots as far back as prehistoric times, with traditions like religious rituals turning stories into immersive experiences. In contrast to linear storytelling, like novels and movies, interactive storytelling allows for nonlinear progression, which means participants can choose their own paths and outcomes. Examples of interactive stories include digital role-playing games and massively multiplayer online games (MMOGs), which have gained popularity alongside advancements in digital technology. Ultimately, these interactive narratives maintain core storytelling elements—characters and events—while offering unique opportunities for audience involvement and the blending of entertainment with educational, informational, and commercial purposes.

parts.title: Early Video Games & Interactive TV Developments
parts.body: Ralph Baer developed the first home console. Original games like a ball and paddle and hockey game were tested as prototypes. Magnavox licensed the technology, launching the Odyssey in 1972 with a dozen games, marking the start of home video games. Atari emerged from an arcade version of a game named Spacewar. Despite their first attempt, Computer Space failing, they introduced Pong in 1972, an engaging ping-pong game that quickly became a success. By the 1980s, arcade and home consoles were thriving. In contrast, interactive television like the Qube system faced challenges, costly to maintain without enough viewership interest. Despite setbacks in the US, Europe saw growth, with France and UK leading interactive programming by the late 1990s.

parts.title: Interactive Character Development
parts.body: Interactive Characters in Digital Media Creating characters for interactive media can be challenging, as they often need to be developed in short scenes or dialogues. Unlike in linear stories, where characters can be gradually built up, in interactive media, it's harder to ensure a consistent buildup due to the non-linear nature. Characters typically lack a character arc and remain unchanged, similar to sitcoms. However, change can be shown through Levels in a story, new skills gained, or how a protagonist's actions impact other characters. A character arc as profound as in films is rare, but games like Final Fantasy VII offer an example. Techniques for richer characters include deep exploration of backstories, clear motivations, and vivid personalities to ensure they stand out.

parts.title: Interactive Entertainment & Learning
parts.body: Interactive Entertainment & Learning: Interactive entertainment can make education more appealing and engaging. It adds interaction and fun, making tasks attractive while maintaining educational integrity. These blends, like edutainment and advergaming, leverage narratives, games, humor, and compelling characters. Educational projects, especially for children, often use rewards like praise and advancement to encourage learners. Role of Entertainment: Entertainment helps reduce intimidation in learning environments, making users comfortable and open to learning by presenting material in a non-judgmental fashion. Projects like the JumpStart series help users practice skills outside traditional classrooms. For more advanced topics, initiatives like MIT’s Games to Teach project integrate complex subjects into engaging formats, aiming to make education accessible through games.

parts.title: Critical Early Steps in Project Development
parts.body: In the development process of interactive projects, essential tasks include defining the project premise, selecting the medium and platform, and ensuring the project fits within a certain genre. A clear description, sometimes called a "log line," helps communicate the project's vision, outlining its core idea and what makes it engaging. This concise premise guides the team's creative brainstorming and informs further planning and production decisions.

parts.title: Adapting Project Plans and Seeking Expertise
parts.body: To develop a successful interactive project, knowing your target audience is crucial. Marketing insights can guide your design and feature decisions. If your initial plan is too costly for the target demographic, you're advised to simplify the design by eliminating expensive features. Alternatively, if another demographic, like teens over preteens, shows more interest, the product might need to be more sophisticated. Throughout the development process, having a preproduction schedule and a budget is vital. These elements help define the project parameters and refine the concept within realistic resource constraints. Bringing in experts for advice or research enriches the content, ensuring it’s informative or adequately reflective of real-world industries like fashion.

parts.title: Innovative Cross-Media Storytelling in "The Beast"
parts.body: In The Beast, a complex cross-media project was created to promote the film AI by Steven Spielberg. The premise involved a murder mystery set in the future, blurring fiction and reality. This immersive experience did not explicitly mention the film and relied on viral marketing. Participants from around the world engaged in activities such as attending fictional rallies or sending condolences to characters, emphasizing participant interaction and narrative depth. This project is a significant example of how storytelling can extend beyond traditional mediums, creating a more engaging narrative experience. Developers of The Beast constructed an intertwined narrative using varied elements like websites, emails, and faxes set in the year 2142. It featured over 50 interconnected websites, each deepening the story's universe. They avoided calling these projects "games" due to their lack of traditional gaming elements like rules or prizes. By utilizing everyday channels, The Beast innovatively merged storytelling with real-world elements, offering a uniquely immersive experience by stepping beyond the constraints of typical virtual reality frameworks.

parts.title: Exploration of Interactive Cinema
parts.body: Interactive Cinema: This chapter discusses different types of interactive cinema, focusing on three distinct scenarios that represent innovative storytelling. Large-screen interactive movies are typically experienced as group events in theaters, where audiences actively participate to shape the narrative. Small-screen movies are for individual engagement, available on DVDs or CD-ROMs. Despite their differences, both share common traits: they are story driven with dimensional characters, blending game-like features with profound narratives. Despite limited production globally, these interactive films continue to break new ground by merging storytelling with audience choice and interactivity.

parts.title: Interactive Movies Overview
parts.body: Interactive Movies Overview Interactive movies have struggled to gain popularity especially in the US, with more interest found in Europe. They're utilized for entertainment, training, and education. One successful company, Immersion Studios in Toronto, has created immersive films for prestigious institutions worldwide. They merge entertainment with educational content mainly tackling scientific themes like biology and pollution. They term their work "immersive cinema" and use a combination of live-action, 3D animation, and gaming elements to envelop audiences with surround sound and visuals. Unlike early models that offered limited interactivity, these productions make the audience feel an essential part of the narrative outcome through personal consoles that allow for deeper exploration, similar to navigating a webpage.

parts.title: Embarking on a Digital Storytelling Career
parts.body: Digital storytellers are pioneers of a new creative endeavor, spanning various technologies and venues, from wireless devices to theme parks. Their work, though diverse, shares common traits: it utilizes digital technologies, tells a story, is entertaining, and involves interactive experiences. This emerging field is in demand, despite not always listing "digital storyteller" in job ads, as roles often go by other titles with various skill requirements. If aspiring to be a digital storyteller, expect a non-linear career path. Many come from varied backgrounds, often following a passion or taking risks, much like Kevin P. Rafferty did, starting as a dishwasher at Disneyland before entering the creative division. He exemplifies that career evolution often involves seizing opportunities and proving creative worth within a company like Disney Imagineering. To sell your ideas for games or interactive entertainment, be aware of market realities and challenges—companies have their own ideas and execution is key, often requiring experience, talent, and investment.
